headline: 'The Five' panel reacts to liberal cities rocket by surge in violence

utterances.speaker: DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello everybody, I'm Dagen McDowell along with Jessica Tarlov, Jesse Watters, Shannon Bream and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5:00 in New York City and this is "The Five." Media darling and America's top doctor, Anthony Fauci is playing some serious defense after a trove of e-mails blew a huge hole in his already shrinking credibility. They revealed his relationship with the Wuhan lab that is facing new scrutiny in the global pandemic that has killed millions. Senator Rand Paul claims Fauci lied to America about that lab potentially doing research that could make viruses more deadly.

utterances.speaker: SEN. RAND PAUL (R-KY)
utterances.sentences: Dr. Fauci still denies it to this day, but in his private e-mails he puts in the subject line, urgent, we must discuss this gain of function research. So, he knows its gain of function and he needs to be pinned down in this. I don't think having trust of Chinese scientist with gain of function research was very wise. In fact, it was so naA_ve that we shouldn't have Dr. Fauci in a position of advising the U.S., the world or anybody else because he shown such poor decision making.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: For some reason, Dr. Fauci refuses to call out China. DR. ANTHONY FAUCI, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS

utterances.speaker: DISEASES
utterances.sentences: The idea I think is quite farfetched that the Chinese deliberately engineered something so that they could kill themselves as well as other people. I mean, obviously, you want openness and cooperation. One of the ways you can get it is don't be accusatory.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: And the White House is standing by Fauci despite the e-mail controversy.

utterances.speaker: JEN PSAKI, WHITE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.sentences: We'll let him speak for himself and he's been an undeniable asset in our country's pandemic response, but it's obviously not that advantageous for me to re-litigate the substance of e- mails from 17 months ago.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Jesse, don't be accusatory.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: He should have had a secret server in his basement, then he just could have wiped it like crooked. These e-mails are bad. I mean, he is on the record of supporting gain of function. He funded gain of function in Wuhan. He knew they were doing gain of function in Wuhan. They had scientists e-mailing him. This thing looks engineered and then now he is on e-mail scrambling to see if his fingerprints are on gain of function. That's not my opinion. Those are the facts. And "Vanity Fair" came out with a big expose blowing the lid off the cover-up. U.S. government telling investigators don't look into this because U.S. money went into this lab, manpower, know how, money. Went into this lab that ended up killing 3.5 million people. This is bigger than 9-11. This is bigger than January 6th. Dare I say, Greg, this might be worse than Watergate.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Not Watergate. Not Watergate.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And the media is complicit in the cover-up. They admitted it. And here's why. The Democrats needed Fauci so they could brand themselves as pro-science. They needed Fauci to lock everything down so they could loosen the state election laws and do the mass mail-out of ballots. And they need Fauci to point the finger away from China and at Trump so they could divide the country for the election. You take Fauci out of the picture, it's like taking a Jenga block out, the whole thing crumbles.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Will they get to the bottom of it, though, Biden and co.? Jessica, they've got what they're looking into it.

utterances.speaker: JESSICA TARLOV, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: I absolutely think that they will. I think the fact that we have moved away from. The WHO already looked into it to we're going to look into ourselves and there is bipartisan support for that. I see no reason that President Biden would stop that in any way and Dr. Fauci is supportive of that as well. To Jesse's point, well first, I love that now Hillary isn't even Hillary. She's just crooked. I assume we've dropped her birth name.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Second of all, you said that the whole Jenga tower falls which included the mail-in ballots which I believe means you're alleging that the election was fraudulent?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, I'm saying it helped loosen the state election laws because everybody had to stay home during the lockdown. You didn't need to lock everybody down. You just needed to isolate the elderly. The rest of the country could have gone about their business. And Fauci was warned to do this by scientists. We saw the e-mails and he ignored it.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Well, Dr. Watters has spoken on that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, he has.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: And we'll come back to that. But from looking at the e-mails, I think that some of it definitely doesn't look fantastic, but he was on with John Berman. We showed a little bit of it, and he talked about that e-mail in February and he clarified that obviously if he had had known what they had known in April and May that he would have told Sylvia Matthews Burwell to wear a mask on a flight. And that we were getting new information from the scientific community as it went along, but I totally agree --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So science wasn't settled?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: No, it wasn't settled.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, so like global warming is not settled?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: No, global warming is pretty much settled.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, that settled, but this science isn't settled. I got it.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Stop playing a game with me. But anyway.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: But Shannon, just on the surface, the most reasonable explanation was, gee whiz, there is a virology lab right in Wuhan while the horseshoe bats lived in caves hundreds of miles away. But instead, the media and Tony Fauci bent over backwards to lean on a hypothesis that wasn't as reasonable and logical as, oh, it came out of a lab that had safety problems because Xi Jin Ping talked about it.

utterances.speaker: SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Well, that gets back to this "Vanity Fair" article that Jesse was talking about. It makes some explosive allegations that people within the State Department were actively telling people shut it down. Don't dig there. Don't go there because you're going to open a Pandora's Box. You heard Dr. Fauci again today saying we have to be careful with China because we need to be able to cooperate with them. It's been over a year. They haven't exactly been transparent with the WHO or anyone else. I'm -- listen, Dagen, I like you grew up in the south and we believe you get more flies with honey but when the flies are full of committing a human rights atrocities and not giving you any information, it's time to get rid of the honey and maybe go with some tabasco or something maybe a little bit stronger.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Yes, the communist party, Greg, if they're talking and breathing, they're lying.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. You know the -- this is the funniest part of the story is they've mentioned the phrase Pandora's Box. That lab literally is a Pandora's Box. They opened it, it got out. So, the idea, like, I always wonder how many investigations are stopped when somebody says that's a Pandora's Box. It's like maybe you should open the Pandora's Box and see what's going on in there. Look, we talked about this last week. One of the reasons why they wanted to blame the wet markets it's not just because of the lab, it's because we are involved in the lab. We have money there. We were thinking, you know, it's the Chinese protecting themselves. No, we're actually trying to protect ourselves because we, if we're -- I mean, these are our experts, these are our scientists. If this was -- consider if these were the plot to a movie, right. Scientists in government engage in highly controversial and risky research. Two, there is an accident. Nobody is saying that this was deliberate.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Fauci kind of blends that together. So, this research accidentally has unleashed into the public a dangerous pathogen, right? The scientists and the experts and the politicians scramble to protect their vital research and cover-up the plausible cause. If that were -- that's a Michael Crichton movie, but it's not. It's real. And I think that's why you have to have an investigation. Is Fauci the villain in this? I just think he is an overly diplomatic bureaucrat. The real villain to me is the media and the Democrats, A, for pushing impeachment exactly, exactly as the virus was exploding. Countless lives were lost because they hated Trump. And number two, labelling anybody a racist who dared to criticize China, that helped -- that steered the debate towards something totally stupid like a pangolin, which still sounds like a musical instrument I wouldn't want to play, but it does have scales.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Whoa, brains.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: I don't -- I would laugh, but I'm in awe of that. But just before we go, will Biden -- because it -- to get to the bottom of this, Joe Biden and company, all the liberals, will have to admit Trump was right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, they can't do that. They can't do that. Also, there is a lot of money at stake. If there's going to be lawsuits, you can't sue China if it's the lab. You got to sue China and the America.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. And the funding started during the Obama-Biden administration.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We need to post-impeach Obama. That is possible, right?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Good luck.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: For this.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Yes, good luck with that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Jessica, we're going to impeach Obama.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Well, we're going to go to break and then we're going to talk about the feasibility of that happening.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Before we go to break though, I'm going to add that I think any Medicare for all, any government-run healthcare is now dead because you look at Tony Fauci and who would want some, you know, spotlight seeking, power hungry career bureaucrat who's some fame floozy decide who gets to live and who dies?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: People without insurance would still prefer that.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: No, they wouldn't.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, that's the emergency room, Jessica, please.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: We all have healthcare in this country. Up next, America under attack. Hackers targeting companies and critical infrastructure and experts warn they are just getting started.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We played that song yesterday. I just want to point that out. I'm pretty sure we did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Another Beastie Boys song.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: America suffering from major cyberattacks and national security experts say hackers are just getting started. A key pipeline and a major meat supplier were targeted in less than a month. And now a cyber-criminal could mess with your commute. New York City's transit authority just reported a breach that happened back in April. The White House in some case seems to be downplaying these cyber threat.

utterances.speaker: PSAKI
utterances.sentences: I would say these are private sector entities who have a responsibility to put in place measures to protect their own cyber security. As it relates to why criminal actors are taking actions against private sector entities, I don't think I'm the right one to speak to that.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: So, a total coincidence?

utterances.speaker: PSAKI
utterances.sentences: I think you could certainly go track down those cyber criminals in Russia and have a good chat with them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: She is so sarcastic about some very serious issues. That reminds me of you, Jessica. So, I have a theory. The reason why the Biden administration is downplaying these assaults is because they are busy up- playing, a word that I just invented right now. You're welcome, America. They are up-playing other issues. For example, the climate crisis should take up 50 percent of your attention and then the remaining 50 percent goes to evil white armies of Caucasian supremacy. So, you cannot worry about this cyber stuff because your brain is filled with evil white men and windmills. That's my theory. I'm sickened to is, Jessica. You have 10 seconds to respond.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Do you remember on "Red Eye" that game where you could just push a button and a liberal only got to talk for 7 seconds.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. I invented that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I need that button. Can I borrow that?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: No. You can't borrow that. So, I disagree --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: -- and I'm sticking to my story. We were actually talking in the greenroom before this, that Leon Panetta was the Defense Secretary in the Obama-Biden administration. He was on with Neil Cavuto in the last hour rooftops. He gave a big speech on the intrepid I believe in 2012 where he talked about how warfare is now going to be fought on the cyber front.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: And I believe it was something that Obama and Biden took seriously. Obviously, our election security is something front and center for all of us. But I don't think that they are downplaying it. I think that they are working as hard as they can alongside the Pentagon to make sure that we stop having these breaches that are affecting, you know, everybody, from Main Street up to big corporations to government hacks at this point. And we know, China and Russia, if they're going to get us, that's how they're going to do it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But they, you know, she said it's a private sector issue. Basically, she's saying --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: So she just respects the private sector, but that doesn't mean they're not working together. Remember like with Apple and opening up the San Bernardino killer's phone. The public face of it was it's a private sector problem, but they were like, excuse me, open this phone. And then we got in the phone.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We don't have phones like that anymore, Jessica.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Liberals do.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Okay. So, evil Shannon Bream, they're targeting our commute. I mean, that's pretty serious because no one wants to get stuck on a subway when it shuts down. Imagine what that's like. Like imagine if you're stuck in a New York City subway train.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You're dead.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You're dead. Yes, you're dead.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: You don't want that during summertime which is the last time I got stuck in there. It's approximately 4,000 degrees Celsius and it smells like dead rats and body stuff. It's not good. I found down a rabbit hole reading about this stuff. I was reading about a guy who was one of a handful of people who is a ransom-ware negotiator. And he talked about this is a much bigger problem than you realize. He says it happens to small and midsized companies all the time. He's called in to talk with them. And you know, the FBI, the government, tells these private companies you can't negotiate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: It's only going to encourage the behavior. He's like, what do you tell a hospital or a school, like you can't give chemo treatments today because you can't negotiate with these guys. And he said it's actually been franchised. So they have people that have a script now who are franchised out by these big crime syndicates who say this is what you say in the first offer. This is how much money I want. This is how -- I mean, it is absolutely insane how much is happening. We only hear about this stuff like the gas pipelines and the beef. Don't mess with the chicken because if the Chik-fil-A gets involved, then we're going to have a problem.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. But do you know what you are talking about? The only way Americans are going to care about this a lot, Jesse, is if their private information is black mailed. If somebody gets all of your e-mails or all of those photos up on the cloud, Jesse, that you thought no one could see. And imagine if it's on to one and one of these free agents goes to you and says like, 10 grand or 30 grand or we drop this stuff. That's not just the plausibility. That's going to happen. If this is happening, that's going to happen, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, Hunter's stuff is already out there, and they said that was fake news.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Good thing Biden is working so hard, Jessica. Actually, he's not. He took the day off. He took the day off.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: It was Jill's birthday.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: It's the First Lady's birthday.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay. It's Thursday. He is the president.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: I don't take the day off for my birthday.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, I don't even take Thursdays off. He is riding bikes in Delaware. People are hacking us to bits in pieces. He doesn't even know there is a cyber-war. They hacked Hillary's campaign manager and the Democrats wanted to restart World War III. Now they have big beef and big oil and Jen Psaki says, it's the private sector. They can fight the war. Private sectors here in America. It's on the homeland. I mean, you're basically telling the terrorists these are targets the president is not going to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What if they bombed a private business? Is that, well, it's a private sector business?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, do they have to go up to Whole Foods for the Democrats to care? They actually went after the ferry to Martha's Vineyard.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Next, what are they going to do? The Hampton Jitney?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, god, no! God, no.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Excel Express (ph)? Democrats won't have anywhere to go after that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, but I said this yesterday. They have to bring back the Bush doctrine, which says right now, they're not operating with the tacit approval of the Kremlin in Russia. So you hold Putin accountable. That's how you do it. Biden's going to go over to Switzerland and sit down with Vladimir at the summit and he's going to say knock it off. They're going to release a read out that says Biden says Putin knock it off and then CNN is going to say Biden is so tough on Russia. No. Biden has to do something to Russia to make Russia feel pain so they don't do it again. Until he does that, they're going to keep hacking.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So, on the business side of this, are there companies out there that could make -- like the private sector that can prevent these things from happening? Where are -- do they exist, that have backups for these companies in case they are compromised or?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Yes, and you saw how with the MTA here in New York City how quickly that hack was resolved. Part of the problem is, and it is on the private sector, they spend money on technology that can yield a profit. They don't necessarily over -- throughout modern history, spend money on something that they can't quantify --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's not worth it to them.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: -- net income on the other end, which is safety. But to Jesse's point, this Joe Biden's opportunity to be a bad ass.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: All he has to do is come out and just -- I wrote a little -- a tiny little speech for him. If you attack the United States and any vital infrastructure or services, there is no safe place on this planet for you. We will come for you and we will kill you. If you are a pipeline, air traffic control, it doesn't matter. If a nation is behind the cyber-crime, we will treat you as if this as an act of war. If it's an individual, we will treat you as a terrorist. There is nowhere to hide on this Earth. He could call it the Biden doctrine, but he is busy eating cake and hiding somewhere in the White House.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know, if these hackers were only white supremacists, we would already be on top of this stuff. Ahead, free to attack people, the guy who sucker punched an Asian woman was arrested four times for assault this year.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Liberal policies being blamed for a horrific hate crime attack in New York City. The suspect who sucker punched an Asian woman should not have never been out on the street, with a staggering 40 prior arrest and four happening in the last year alone for a similar random assault. The NYPD's commissioner is fed up and is blaming bail reform.

utterances.speaker: DERMOT SHEA, NEW YORK CITY POLICE COMMISSIONER
utterances.sentences: People that are arrested multiple, multiple, multiple times and released. You know, mental illness is woven into this potentially. We have to do better. And Pat (ph), we are arresting somebody for pushing a woman down the stairs and then we release them back on the streets? I mean, this is craziness.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So a guy like this, Gutfeld, 40 prior arrests. He is like a hand grenade. You don't keep putting a hand grenade out on the street.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Isn't he the real victim though? You know, it is amazing to me how the left can condemn every single micro aggression, but when there is real aggression --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Good point.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- fist to face, its crickets or cicadas.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: Cicadas.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Cicadas. We learned a couple of lessons here in the world of cause and effect, we need prisons. I am a libertarian, but we need prisons. You release violent offenders who re-offend into the streets, they re-offend. The politicians, if they want to release them, they should take them into their own homes. You know, put your money where your mouth is. You don't put them among poor people, elderly people in Chinatown. Sure, the prisons are less crowded, but the E.R. in Chinatown is now full with people with black eyes or bruises. They need to use Kendra's Law more where, you know, you can force -- you know, you can compel the insane, the deranged into treatment. They stopped doing that as much as they used to. If you just drive up one block in New York, you could see it everywhere. These are grown men hitting elderly women, okay. There has to be a class action suit against the city. If you got all these victims together maybe that would make the politicians understand that you can't do this because there seems like there is no retribution. Like you never hear any of the politicians talking about this. We are the only people pointing this out. Why is that? Because there is no retribution. There is no consequences as a politician. They just figure, nobody sees this stuff. The media doesn't care because they don't live in these neighborhoods. They don't' give a damn.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, and if you try to institutionalize someone like this, the ACLU comes along, Shannon, and says, oh no, no, violating his constitutional rights. Well, he can violate anybody else's rights with his fists.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: Yes, my late father was a law enforcement officer so I hear from people who are out there and who have been out there in the front lines all the times. They are so frustrated that if they bothered to do the paper work and arrest someone that now we're going to a lot of prosecutors who don't want to prosecute. There are a lot of places where there is bail reform or they are doing away with enhancements and sentencing and that kind of thing. We've been following, and you guys have to, I mean, several cases of recalls out in California. I think of the LA District Attorney out there Gascon. Now, formal recall underway because crime victims, victims' families of people who've been killed, say this is ridiculous. Now, the guy ran saying he was going to do this stuff. Thousands of inmates there are going to be eligible to have resentencing or maybe get out altogether. So, when you have that going on, and you've got law enforcement officers seeing even if we bring someone in, you guys are going to let them go. It's a bad stew in a lot of big cities right now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's a toxic brew. It's -- you bail reform, bad judges, soft prosecutors, defund the police, Dagen. It adds up to crimes like this.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Liberal parole boards releasing not only cop killers, but child murderers. And now, the idiots in Albany, well, the liberal idiots are pushing forward with even more parole reform. Here's what's going on. When these -- when leaders, politicians, and bureaucrats get asked about these policies that change the subject, because they refuse to own them. They are pro-crime. They have no backbone to stand up for law-abiding citizens and victims. That's how bad it is. And in terms of -- what is wrong with saying that a violent mentally ill person who's a danger to others and himself, who's been arrested dozens of times, needs to be off the street, but somehow that's racist. They're closing Rikers Island, there are thousands of people who've been put out on the street who are walking around and hitting elderly women in the face. That's where we are. It is so -- it's so bad even in San Francisco, though. There were two -- and they want to blame hate crimes. It's a hate crime but it's not because of Trump. There were two elderly women who were stabbed and broad daylight. One woman had part of the knife still stuck in her. The handle broke off. The man who hurt them was supposed to be in prison for 25 years to life, but was led out on a mental health waiver. And they released the X -- the family released the X-ray of this knife stuck in the woman hoping the prosecutor would send the man to jail.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, Jessica, why does your party support old women being assaulted?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: It's hugely popular at the polls.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Serious question.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: This is a very difficult segment to be batting cleanup on. And I know that we have time, so I'm going to try to get really fast through this. Liberals care when people are beaten up and they care no matter what color the perpetrator is. And they've been having a conversation led frankly, by Congresspeople. from the AAPI community like Congresswoman Grace Meng talking about the spike in crime from white and black perpetrators.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We don't need a conversation. We want action, though.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Well, you do need a conversation because that's where reform comes from. And I will say and I wish we --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We know what's the reform that's needed. You get rid of bail reform, and you institutionalize the crazy people.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: No. So, you're a doctor now, and now you're in charge of --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That makes perfect sense.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm a policy expert, Jessica.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Can I add one thing? If you -- if you defend somebody who's being beaten up, or you do or I do because of the color of our skin, we're going to get thrown in jail, we will lose our jobs, we will be on every television network. utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: The Office star Ellie Kemper at the center of a social media controversy. Twitter users discovering decades-old newspaper clippings showing her being named Queen of a controversial debutante ball. Back in 1999, then 19-year-old Kemper was crowned Queen of the veiled prophet ball, an annual event that was founded by St. Louis elites in the late 19 -- 1800s, and excluded African Americans for the first century of its existence. But it has diversified since then decades before Kemper was born or crowned queen. The negative reaction online has been brutal. Some calling her a "KKK Queen." And media headlines say she was "Crowned queen of a racist and elitist ball." I had to dig into this thing to find out what this was all about. It's very strange. And it did have some exclusions, Greg, very early on for Black Americans, for Jewish Americans who was all about white people, and the elite of society and wealthy. They changed things back in the 70s. They said now that they are all about completely turning against that. They are charitable in nature. But it sounds like some people didn't even do some basic --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, no, no. It has nothing to do with this organization. If you wanted to hold this standard, you'd have to -- you'd have to cancel everybody in the Democratic Party, right? They're the -- they're the party of slavery. They're not the party of slavery anymore, they were the party of Jim Crow. They're not the party of Jim Crow anymore, but you see the point. This is absurd. So, how did this happen, all right, these people had no -- the people that are "outraged" had no idea that this organization existed. They barely even knew her except for the Office. They never -- and they never bothered to do the research because it's a memetic mob. It's a symptom of a lonely bored ambivalent population. So, what caused them to do this? Twitter trends, not Twitter, not Twitter. Because if you don't look at Twitter trends, you don't know what's trending at all. You just see what's in front of you. But if you got rid of Twitter trends, what happens is that's a sorting mechanism that shows you that stuff that's bubbling up. So, one person who doesn't like her who went to high school with her put a clipping on there, it starts trending, right? And then everybody starts piling on and piling on. It indulges your mimetic desire to be part of a mob. If Jack Dorsey wanted to win a Nobel Prize, he could say, Twitter going forward will have no Twitter trends because I realized that that triggers the mob. And I'm telling you, cancel culture, if you took down Twitter trends, canceled culture would disappear probably in a week, because you can't find out what to cancel. How can you find out what to cancel if there's no Twitter trend?

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: Right. And you have to be -- find out what to be angry about.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: No one is going to tell you. I would give them the Pulitzer for the mute button, though, because that's pretty helpful.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: BREAM

And what I love is the employee who gave it to her was a guy who's worked there 35 years. He's got cerebral palsy too. And he told her, you can do anything. I love it, Lincoln.

utterances.utterance: Well, we're going to go to break and then we're going to talk about the feasibility of that happening.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Before we go to break though, I'm going to add that I think any Medicare for all, any government-run healthcare is now dead because you look at Tony Fauci and who would want some, you know, spotlight seeking, power hungry career bureaucrat who's some fame floozy decide who gets to live and who dies?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: People without insurance would still prefer that.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: No, they wouldn't.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, that's the emergency room, Jessica, please.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: We all have healthcare in this country. Up next, America under attack. Hackers targeting companies and critical infrastructure and experts warn they are just getting started.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We played that song yesterday. I just want to point that out. I'm pretty sure we did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Another Beastie Boys song.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: America suffering from major cyberattacks and national security experts say hackers are just getting started. A key pipeline and a major meat supplier were targeted in less than a month. And now a cyber-criminal could mess with your commute. New York City's transit authority just reported a breach that happened back in April. The White House in some case seems to be downplaying these cyber threat.

utterances.speaker: PSAKI
utterances.utterance: I would say these are private sector entities who have a responsibility to put in place measures to protect their own cyber security. As it relates to why criminal actors are taking actions against private sector entities, I don't think I'm the right one to speak to that.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.utterance: So, a total coincidence?

utterances.speaker: PSAKI
utterances.utterance: I think you could certainly go track down those cyber criminals in Russia and have a good chat with them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She is so sarcastic about some very serious issues. That reminds me of you, Jessica. So, I have a theory. The reason why the Biden administration is downplaying these assaults is because they are busy up- playing, a word that I just invented right now. You're welcome, America. They are up-playing other issues. For example, the climate crisis should take up 50 percent of your attention and then the remaining 50 percent goes to evil white armies of Caucasian supremacy. So, you cannot worry about this cyber stuff because your brain is filled with evil white men and windmills. That's my theory. I'm sickened to is, Jessica. You have 10 seconds to respond.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Do you remember on "Red Eye" that game where you could just push a button and a liberal only got to talk for 7 seconds.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I invented that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I need that button. Can I borrow that?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: No. You can't borrow that. So, I disagree --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: -- and I'm sticking to my story. We were actually talking in the greenroom before this, that Leon Panetta was the Defense Secretary in the Obama-Biden administration. He was on with Neil Cavuto in the last hour rooftops. He gave a big speech on the intrepid I believe in 2012 where he talked about how warfare is now going to be fought on the cyber front.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: And I believe it was something that Obama and Biden took seriously. Obviously, our election security is something front and center for all of us. But I don't think that they are downplaying it. I think that they are working as hard as they can alongside the Pentagon to make sure that we stop having these breaches that are affecting, you know, everybody, from Main Street up to big corporations to government hacks at this point. And we know, China and Russia, if they're going to get us, that's how they're going to do it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But they, you know, she said it's a private sector issue. Basically, she's saying --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: So she just respects the private sector, but that doesn't mean they're not working together. Remember like with Apple and opening up the San Bernardino killer's phone. The public face of it was it's a private sector problem, but they were like, excuse me, open this phone. And then we got in the phone.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We don't have phones like that anymore, Jessica.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Liberals do.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Okay. So, evil Shannon Bream, they're targeting our commute. I mean, that's pretty serious because no one wants to get stuck on a subway when it shuts down. Imagine what that's like. Like imagine if you're stuck in a New York City subway train.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're dead.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're dead. Yes, you're dead.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: You don't want that during summertime which is the last time I got stuck in there. It's approximately 4,000 degrees Celsius and it smells like dead rats and body stuff. It's not good. I found down a rabbit hole reading about this stuff. I was reading about a guy who was one of a handful of people who is a ransom-ware negotiator. And he talked about this is a much bigger problem than you realize. He says it happens to small and midsized companies all the time. He's called in to talk with them. And you know, the FBI, the government, tells these private companies you can't negotiate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: It's only going to encourage the behavior. He's like, what do you tell a hospital or a school, like you can't give chemo treatments today because you can't negotiate with these guys. And he said it's actually been franchised. So they have people that have a script now who are franchised out by these big crime syndicates who say this is what you say in the first offer. This is how much money I want. This is how -- I mean, it is absolutely insane how much is happening. We only hear about this stuff like the gas pipelines and the beef. Don't mess with the chicken because if the Chik-fil-A gets involved, then we're going to have a problem.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. But do you know what you are talking about? The only way Americans are going to care about this a lot, Jesse, is if their private information is black mailed. If somebody gets all of your e-mails or all of those photos up on the cloud, Jesse, that you thought no one could see. And imagine if it's on to one and one of these free agents goes to you and says like, 10 grand or 30 grand or we drop this stuff. That's not just the plausibility. That's going to happen. If this is happening, that's going to happen, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I mean, Hunter's stuff is already out there, and they said that was fake news.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Good thing Biden is working so hard, Jessica. Actually, he's not. He took the day off. He took the day off.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: It was Jill's birthday.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: It's the First Lady's birthday.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay. It's Thursday. He is the president.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: I don't take the day off for my birthday.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. I mean, I don't even take Thursdays off. He is riding bikes in Delaware. People are hacking us to bits in pieces. He doesn't even know there is a cyber-war. They hacked Hillary's campaign manager and the Democrats wanted to restart World War III. Now they have big beef and big oil and Jen Psaki says, it's the private sector. They can fight the war. Private sectors here in America. It's on the homeland. I mean, you're basically telling the terrorists these are targets the president is not going to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What if they bombed a private business? Is that, well, it's a private sector business?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. I mean, do they have to go up to Whole Foods for the Democrats to care? They actually went after the ferry to Martha's Vineyard.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Next, what are they going to do? The Hampton Jitney?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, god, no! God, no.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Excel Express (ph)? Democrats won't have anywhere to go after that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, but I said this yesterday. They have to bring back the Bush doctrine, which says right now, they're not operating with the tacit approval of the Kremlin in Russia. So you hold Putin accountable. That's how you do it. Biden's going to go over to Switzerland and sit down with Vladimir at the summit and he's going to say knock it off. They're going to release a read out that says Biden says Putin knock it off and then CNN is going to say Biden is so tough on Russia. No. Biden has to do something to Russia to make Russia feel pain so they don't do it again. Until he does that, they're going to keep hacking.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, on the business side of this, are there companies out there that could make -- like the private sector that can prevent these things from happening? Where are -- do they exist, that have backups for these companies in case they are compromised or?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Yes, and you saw how with the MTA here in New York City how quickly that hack was resolved. Part of the problem is, and it is on the private sector, they spend money on technology that can yield a profit. They don't necessarily over -- throughout modern history, spend money on something that they can't quantify --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's not worth it to them.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: -- net income on the other end, which is safety. But to Jesse's point, this Joe Biden's opportunity to be a bad ass.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: All he has to do is come out and just -- I wrote a little -- a tiny little speech for him. If you attack the United States and any vital infrastructure or services, there is no safe place on this planet for you. We will come for you and we will kill you. If you are a pipeline, air traffic control, it doesn't matter. If a nation is behind the cyber-crime, we will treat you as if this as an act of war. If it's an individual, we will treat you as a terrorist. There is nowhere to hide on this Earth. He could call it the Biden doctrine, but he is busy eating cake and hiding somewhere in the White House.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, if these hackers were only white supremacists, we would already be on top of this stuff. Ahead, free to attack people, the guy who sucker punched an Asian woman was arrested four times for assault this year.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Liberal policies being blamed for a horrific hate crime attack in New York City. The suspect who sucker punched an Asian woman should not have never been out on the street, with a staggering 40 prior arrest and four happening in the last year alone for a similar random assault. The NYPD's commissioner is fed up and is blaming bail reform.

utterances.speaker: DERMOT SHEA, NEW YORK CITY POLICE COMMISSIONER
utterances.utterance: People that are arrested multiple, multiple, multiple times and released. You know, mental illness is woven into this potentially. We have to do better. And Pat (ph), we are arresting somebody for pushing a woman down the stairs and then we release them back on the streets? I mean, this is craziness.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So a guy like this, Gutfeld, 40 prior arrests. He is like a hand grenade. You don't keep putting a hand grenade out on the street.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Isn't he the real victim though? You know, it is amazing to me how the left can condemn every single micro aggression, but when there is real aggression --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Good point.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- fist to face, its crickets or cicadas.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Cicadas.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Cicadas. We learned a couple of lessons here in the world of cause and effect, we need prisons. I am a libertarian, but we need prisons. You release violent offenders who re-offend into the streets, they re-offend. The politicians, if they want to release them, they should take them into their own homes. You know, put your money where your mouth is. You don't put them among poor people, elderly people in Chinatown. Sure, the prisons are less crowded, but the E.R. in Chinatown is now full with people with black eyes or bruises. They need to use Kendra's Law more where, you know, you can force -- you know, you can compel the insane, the deranged into treatment. They stopped doing that as much as they used to. If you just drive up one block in New York, you could see it everywhere. These are grown men hitting elderly women, okay. There has to be a class action suit against the city. If you got all these victims together maybe that would make the politicians understand that you can't do this because there seems like there is no retribution. Like you never hear any of the politicians talking about this. We are the only people pointing this out. Why is that? Because there is no retribution. There is no consequences as a politician. They just figure, nobody sees this stuff. The media doesn't care because they don't live in these neighborhoods. They don't' give a damn.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, and if you try to institutionalize someone like this, the ACLU comes along, Shannon, and says, oh no, no, violating his constitutional rights. Well, he can violate anybody else's rights with his fists.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Yes, my late father was a law enforcement officer so I hear from people who are out there and who have been out there in the front lines all the times. They are so frustrated that if they bothered to do the paper work and arrest someone that now we're going to a lot of prosecutors who don't want to prosecute. There are a lot of places where there is bail reform or they are doing away with enhancements and sentencing and that kind of thing. We've been following, and you guys have to, I mean, several cases of recalls out in California. I think of the LA District Attorney out there Gascon. Now, formal recall underway because crime victims, victims' families of people who've been killed, say this is ridiculous. Now, the guy ran saying he was going to do this stuff. Thousands of inmates there are going to be eligible to have resentencing or maybe get out altogether. So, when you have that going on, and you've got law enforcement officers seeing even if we bring someone in, you guys are going to let them go. It's a bad stew in a lot of big cities right now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's a toxic brew. It's -- you bail reform, bad judges, soft prosecutors, defund the police, Dagen. It adds up to crimes like this.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Liberal parole boards releasing not only cop killers, but child murderers. And now, the idiots in Albany, well, the liberal idiots are pushing forward with even more parole reform. Here's what's going on. When these -- when leaders, politicians, and bureaucrats get asked about these policies that change the subject, because they refuse to own them. They are pro-crime. They have no backbone to stand up for law-abiding citizens and victims. That's how bad it is. And in terms of -- what is wrong with saying that a violent mentally ill person who's a danger to others and himself, who's been arrested dozens of times, needs to be off the street, but somehow that's racist. They're closing Rikers Island, there are thousands of people who've been put out on the street who are walking around and hitting elderly women in the face. That's where we are. It is so -- it's so bad even in San Francisco, though. There were two -- and they want to blame hate crimes. It's a hate crime but it's not because of Trump. There were two elderly women who were stabbed and broad daylight. One woman had part of the knife still stuck in her. The handle broke off. The man who hurt them was supposed to be in prison for 25 years to life, but was led out on a mental health waiver. And they released the X -- the family released the X-ray of this knife stuck in the woman hoping the prosecutor would send the man to jail.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, Jessica, why does your party support old women being assaulted?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: It's hugely popular at the polls.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Serious question.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: This is a very difficult segment to be batting cleanup on. And I know that we have time, so I'm going to try to get really fast through this. Liberals care when people are beaten up and they care no matter what color the perpetrator is. And they've been having a conversation led frankly, by Congresspeople. from the AAPI community like Congresswoman Grace Meng talking about the spike in crime from white and black perpetrators.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We don't need a conversation. We want action, though.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Well, you do need a conversation because that's where reform comes from. And I will say and I wish we --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We know what's the reform that's needed. You get rid of bail reform, and you institutionalize the crazy people.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: No. So, you're a doctor now, and now you're in charge of --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That makes perfect sense.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm a policy expert, Jessica.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Can I add one thing? If you -- if you defend somebody who's being beaten up, or you do or I do because of the color of our skin, we're going to get thrown in jail, we will lose our jobs, we will be on every television network. That's what it is. So, if I tackle somebody in the street, it's going to happen. It's a one-way crime.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: As a -- as a parting shot, I hope that my colleagues here would agree that there's no way in hell that I wouldn't care that old Asian people are getting punched in the street in Chinatown. And I think that that is true from top to bottom on the Democratic side now. There are disagreements --

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: (INAUDIBLE) Garcia, who's pro-cop -- pro-crime and anti-cop.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I believe that -- I believe that's true, but I don't believe the second part that the Democrats cared about this. They only cared about it when they found that white -- that white murderer in Atlanta who killed those women at the --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: The spa shooter?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- at the massage parlors, and then they found that it was more about a -- he was insane into sex crime kind of thing. It was about sex. Then all of these Asian hate crimes started but they couldn't pin it on a white movement. They don't care -- if they can't make it about race, Jessica, they don't do anything about it. They call voter ID an existential risk to our democracy. But if you bring up black on black crime in Chicago, all the majority of the victims are black, they will call you racist or they'll just say, that's gang crime. That that's a problem.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, you got your 10 seconds. We got to go. Up next, cancel culture coming for Office star Ellie Kemper over something she did decades ago.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: The Office star Ellie Kemper at the center of a social media controversy. Twitter users discovering decades-old newspaper clippings showing her being named Queen of a controversial debutante ball. Back in 1999, then 19-year-old Kemper was crowned Queen of the veiled prophet ball, an annual event that was founded by St. Louis elites in the late 19 -- 1800s, and excluded African Americans for the first century of its existence. But it has diversified since then decades before Kemper was born or crowned queen. The negative reaction online has been brutal. Some calling her a "KKK Queen." And media headlines say she was "Crowned queen of a racist and elitist ball." I had to dig into this thing to find out what this was all about. It's very strange. And it did have some exclusions, Greg, very early on for Black Americans, for Jewish Americans who was all about white people, and the elite of society and wealthy. They changed things back in the 70s. They said now that they are all about completely turning against that. They are charitable in nature. But it sounds like some people didn't even do some basic --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. It has nothing to do with this organization. If you wanted to hold this standard, you'd have to -- you'd have to cancel everybody in the Democratic Party, right? They're the -- they're the party of slavery. They're not the party of slavery anymore, they were the party of Jim Crow. They're not the party of Jim Crow anymore, but you see the point. This is absurd. So, how did this happen, all right, these people had no -- the people that are "outraged" had no idea that this organization existed. They barely even knew her except for the Office. They never -- and they never bothered to do the research because it's a memetic mob. It's a symptom of a lonely bored ambivalent population. So, what caused them to do this? Twitter trends, not Twitter, not Twitter. Because if you don't look at Twitter trends, you don't know what's trending at all. You just see what's in front of you. But if you got rid of Twitter trends, what happens is that's a sorting mechanism that shows you that stuff that's bubbling up. So, one person who doesn't like her who went to high school with her put a clipping on there, it starts trending, right? And then everybody starts piling on and piling on. It indulges your mimetic desire to be part of a mob. If Jack Dorsey wanted to win a Nobel Prize, he could say, Twitter going forward will have no Twitter trends because I realized that that triggers the mob. And I'm telling you, cancel culture, if you took down Twitter trends, canceled culture would disappear probably in a week, because you can't find out what to cancel. How can you find out what to cancel if there's no Twitter trend?

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Right. And you have to be -- find out what to be angry about.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: No one is going to tell you. I would give them the Pulitzer for the mute button, though, because that's pretty helpful.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's true.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Dagen, do you -- do you worry that things like this in any way take away from real concrete examples of racism that do need to be addressed?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Yes, like I've got one on my list. The bigger deal is Google's head of diversity. It was discovered, wrote back in 2007 that Jews have an insatiable appetite for war and killing, and an insensitivity to people suffering. This is back in 2007. The man has a Ph.D. He still got a job at Google. He got benched from heading diversity. That was -- that was brain surgery to make that decision. But -- and he also addressed his apology to a distribution list at Google titled jugglers which I think deserves some attention. So, why is that OK? Why -- did he miss the Holocaust when he was studying for his PhD? So, I'm mad about that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. There you go.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: So, Jesse, clearly a troubled past for this organization. They've tried to make changes. So, they're acknowledging there have been some things that were not positive.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean, I'm mad as Steve Carell. He honestly should have had her back. Why didn't he come to her defense? If something happened with Greg --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: True.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know what I would do? I'd wait to see what Dana did first, and then I'd probably defend him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Where's Rainn Wilson?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Where is Rainn Wilson? Where is Krasinski? Where's her friends. This is sick. But I have to give you credit, if you do eliminate Twitter trends, I'm mad I didn't think of this, that would really eliminate 50 percent of canceled culture. You also made another good point. I can't believe I'm just doubling down on all these phrase, you're going to get a bigger head, that the Democratic Party has a bigger connection to white supremacy and slavery than just about anything in this country, not the ball. I honestly think there are a lot of Democrats who were ashamed to be members of a party that went to war to keep their slaves. So, what they do is they project all of this white supremacy and racism on Republicans, the party that freed the slaves.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Jessica, do you think that she should have known about the troublesome history of this group at 19? Wouldn't -- they say they had cleaned up their act by then?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: At 19, no. Yes, I would love it if everybody had a perfect track record with this. And I think that we can all agree that Ellie Kemper is probably not a top the list of people who you think was getting really pumped to go be -- crowned queen of an organization that used to not allow Jews and blacks. So, it's also -- when people pick these characters that basically no one is going to go along with, right, like it's just not believable that Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt is harboring this deep-seated hatred for people of color, for people, you know, minority religion, like myself, that diversity had the Google story really as a -- as a Jewish person was quite over the top.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Think about Major League Baseball. Like, regionally -- if you were upset about this, you should be upset at every player who plays Major League Baseball. When -- were they no longer segregated?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Greg, all the Country Club that these executives belong to, do they allow Jews and Blacks and do they have a history of discriminating against Jews or Blacks. It may be some investigative reporter could look at all the country clubs that these executives belong to, and make them be canceled.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: And listen, Jesse says he's going to, you know, defend Greg from every build of the ball. And you're going to stay busy. There have been many balls.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. You were the build of the ball.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I was the original one.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Many balls -- many balls for Greg. OK, cicadas are taking over the country, and now some Americans are being warned not to eat them. Are you one of them?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Billions of creepy-looking cicadas are rising up across 15 states. And some Americans are actually eating them. Well, at least on one network.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Oh, the crunch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Do you I have a wing hanging on in my mouth? It's literally in there.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It's not a wing. It's a -- it's a leg

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: That's actually quite delicious.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Americans are chowing down on these bugs that the FDA had to issue a warning, saying eating cicadas could be dangerous if you have a seafood allergy. So, Shannon, you're the only person here who lives in Washington D.C. with cicada hub.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: It is.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Tell us about your friends.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: I think that we have the sound that you can hear when I walk outside. It's so loud right now. I can hear it inside. It's just constant and never goes away. They are carcasses everywhere. When I go for my runs every day, it's crunchy. It literally is crunchy because they're everywhere. My dog will not stop eating. I have to say this really quick. The U.N. says we shouldn't be making fun of eating insects because they're highly nutritious. They could be a healthy food source, high in fat, protein, vitamins, fiber, and mineral. If I'm going to splurge on something high in fat, it is not going to be a crunchy bug.
